supporting.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used civil calendar, defines a common year as consisting of 365 days.

attacks.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used civil calendar, defines a common year as consisting of 365 days.
Leap years, which occur every 4 years, have 366 days to account for the Earth's orbit taking approximately 365.25 days.
The Gregorian calendar skips leap years on years divisible by 100 but not by 400, making the average year length 365.2425 days.
Some specialized calendars, like the lunar calendar, have years with significantly fewer days, challenging the universality of the 365-day claim.

supporting.text: Astronomical measurements confirm that Earth's orbital period around the Sun is approximately 365.25 days, with common years rounded to 365 days.

attacks.text: Astronomical measurements confirm that Earth's orbital period around the Sun is approximately 365.25 days, with common years rounded to 365 days.
Leap years add an extra day every four years to account for the 0.25-day discrepancy, making the average year length 365.25 days.
The Gregorian calendar further adjusts leap years by omitting them in years divisible by 100 but not by 400, refining the average year length to 365.2425 days.
Even with these adjustments, the Gregorian calendar still has a slight error of about 26 seconds per year, which accumulates over centuries.

supporting.text: Standard timekeeping systems and international agreements universally recognize a non-leap year as having 365 days.

attacks.text: Standard timekeeping systems and international agreements universally recognize a non-leap year as having 365 days.

The Gregorian calendar is internationally standardized for civil use, making other calendars largely irrelevant for general timekeeping.
